page.title: 09A Welbeck Miner's Thoughts
page.content: When Tom Moody started in 1943, training was very haphazard.Tom merely watched the miner he was assigned to for a couple of days before doing the job himself.Nowadays apprenticeship schemes have led to better educated workers and the local apprentices attend Lound Hall,near Bevercotes Colliery for several weeks before even seeing the coalface.Tom was working on the coal face after 3 days! Wages have obviously changed.In 1943 Tom earned 24/3d (Â£1.21) per week.Now a new face-worker earns Â£150 per week plus bonus.Mr Moody feels however, that there was far more discipline and pride amongst the miners in 1943 than there is today,but that discipline is gradually returning. At Welbeck today the coalface is the safest place in the pit.Tom would not like to go back to 1943 conditions.
